src.training.configs module¶

Configuration dataclasses for training scripts (SFT/GRPO).

class src.training.configs.GRPOConfig(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]¶

Bases: GRPOConfig

Thin wrapper around trl.GRPOConfig for type-checking.

All project-specific training options live in separate dataclasses (ChatBenchmarkConfig, HubRevisionConfig, WandbRunConfig, GRPOOnlyTrainingConfig) which are merged into an instance of this class at CLI parse time.

class src.training.configs.GRPOCosineRewardConfig(cosine_min_value_wrong: float = 0.0, cosine_max_value_wrong: float = -0.5, cosine_min_value_correct: float = 0.5, cosine_max_value_correct: float = 1.0, cosine_max_len: int = 1000)[source]¶

Bases: object

Cosine-scaling parameters for GRPO reward shaping.

Parameters:

  • cosine_min_value_wrong (float) – Minimum reward for cosine scaling for wrong answers.

  • cosine_max_value_wrong (float) – Maximum reward for cosine scaling for wrong answers.

  • cosine_min_value_correct (float) – Minimum reward for cosine scaling for correct answers.

  • cosine_max_value_correct (float) – Maximum reward for cosine scaling for correct answers.

  • cosine_max_len (int) – Maximum length for cosine scaling.

cosine_max_len: int = 1000¶
cosine_max_value_correct: float = 1.0¶
cosine_max_value_wrong: float = -0.5¶
cosine_min_value_correct: float = 0.5¶
cosine_min_value_wrong: float = 0.0¶
class src.training.configs.GRPODatasetColumnsConfig(dataset_prompt_column: str = 'problem', dataset_solution_column: str = 'answer', max_completion_len: int = 16384, soft_punish_cache: int = 4096)[source]¶

Bases: object

Dataset column and generation-length parameters for GRPO.

Parameters:

  • dataset_prompt_column (str) – Column to use as prompts for training.

  • dataset_solution_column (str) – Column to use as the gold solution/answer for training.

  • max_completion_len (int) – Maximum number of characters in completion.

  • soft_punish_cache (int) – Minimum number of characters in completion.

dataset_prompt_column: str = 'problem'¶

Bases: object

Reward-related script arguments for the GRPO training script.

Parameters:

  • reward_funcs (list[str]) – List of reward functions. Possible values: ‘accuracy’, ‘format’, ‘reasoning_steps’, ‘cosine’, ‘repetition_penalty’, ‘length’, ‘tag_count’.

  • repetition_n_grams (int) – Number of n-grams for repetition penalty reward.

  • repetition_max_penalty (float) – Maximum (negative) penalty for repetition penalty reward.

repetition_max_penalty: float = -1.0¶
repetition_n_grams: int = 3¶
reward_funcs: list[str]¶
class src.training.configs.GRPOScriptArguments(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]¶

Bases: ScriptArguments

Base script arguments for the GRPO training script.

GRPO-specific options are provided via separate dataclasses (GRPORewardConfig, GRPOCosineRewardConfig, GRPODatasetColumnsConfig, GRPOSpanKLConfig) and merged into an instance of this class at CLI parse time.

class src.training.configs.SFTConfig(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]¶

Bases: SFTConfig

Thin wrapper around trl.SFTConfig for type-checking.

Project-specific training options are provided by ChatBenchmarkConfig, HubRevisionConfig, and WandbRunConfig and merged into instances of this class by callers.

class src.training.configs.ScriptArguments(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]¶

Bases: ScriptArguments

Extended version of trl.ScriptArguments with support for dataset mixtures.

Parameters:

dataset_mixture (dict[str, Any] | None) –

Optional configuration for creating dataset mixtures with advanced options. Example structure:

dataset_mixture:
  datasets:
    - id: dataset_id1
      config: config_name
      columns:
        - col1
        - col2
      weight: 0.5
    - id: dataset_id2
      config: config_name
      columns:
        - col1
        - col2
      weight: 0.5
  seed: 42
  test_split_size: 0.1

dataset_mixture: dict[str, Any] | None = None¶
dataset_name: str | None = None¶

src.training.configs.merge_dataclass_attributes(target: Any, *configs: Any) → Any[source]¶

Copy all fields from one or more dataclass instances onto target.

This is used to keep the configuration objects that external code sees (GRPOConfig, SFTConfig, GRPOScriptArguments) small and tidy while still exposing a flat attribute namespace at runtime.

src.training.generate.build_distilabel_pipeline(model: str, base_url: str = 'http://localhost:8000/v1', config: DistilabelPipelineConfig | None = None)[source]¶

Build and configure a distilabel Pipeline for text generation.

Parameters:

  • model – Model name or identifier understood by the distilabel/OpenAI LLM client.

  • base_url – Base URL of the vLLM (or OpenAI-compatible) server.

  • config – Optional DistilabelPipelineConfig describing prompt, batching, and generation settings. When None, a default config is used.

Returns:

A configured distilabel Pipeline object with a single TextGeneration step attached.

Raises:

RuntimeError – If the distilabel package is not installed.

src.training.grpo module¶

Public GRPO CLI shim.

This module remains import-compatible (python -m training.grpo) while the real implementation now lives under src.training.cli.grpo.

src.training.grpo.main() → None[source]¶

Delegate to the CLI entrypoint, allowing tests to patch merge helpers.

src.training.grpo.merge_dataclass_attributes(target: Any, *configs: Any) → Any[source]¶

Copy all fields from one or more dataclass instances onto target.

This is used to keep the configuration objects that external code sees (GRPOConfig, SFTConfig, GRPOScriptArguments) small and tidy while still exposing a flat attribute namespace at runtime.

src.training.grpo_dataset module¶

Dataset helpers for GRPO training (chat formatting and easy-pool loading).

src.training.grpo_impl module¶

Compatibility wrapper around the full GRPO implementation.

The heavy implementation lives in src.training.grpo_runtime. This module exists so external callers can continue to import training.grpo_impl while keeping this file small enough to satisfy linting limits.

src.training.grpo_impl.main(script_args, training_args, model_args)[source]¶

Entry point for GRPO training with replay buffer and EASY/CRYPTIC mixing.

src.training.grpo_rewards_router module¶

Task-aware reward routing and nested-completion helpers for GRPO training.

src.training.grpo_rewards_router.reward_router(*, prompts=None, completions=None, tasks=None, proc=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Route completion rewards to the appropriate task-specific scorer.

  • For RUSH tasks, uses rush_solution_shaped() with optional board-size and move-sequence hints.

  • For MATH tasks, uses pure_accuracy_reward_math().

  • Otherwise, defaults to crossword-style pure_accuracy_reward() with shaping.

Nested B×K completions are handled transparently via the helpers in this module.

Parameters:

  • prompts – Prompt text or list of prompts corresponding to completions.

  • completions – Single completion, list of completions, or nested list of completions per example.

  • tasks – Optional explicit task label(s); when omitted, task is inferred from script arguments or prompts.

  • proc – Optional tokenizer/processor exposing a decode method for converting token IDs to strings.

  • kwargs – Additional keyword arguments, including optional script_args, gold/answers/labels and Rush Hour hints such as gold_moves, board_str, and N.

Returns:

List of per-sample reward scores (flat or nested, matching the completion structure).

src.training.grpo_runtime module¶

Backward-compatible alias for the relocated GRPO runtime entrypoint.

src.training.grpo_trainer_replay module¶

Compatibility wrapper exposing the GRPO replay trainer stack.

This module re-exports the replay-enabled trainer and related helper dataclasses defined in src.training.grpo_runtime_impl_full so that callers can import them from a smaller, focused namespace.

src.training.grpo_trainer_replay_support module¶

Helper types and utilities for the GRPO replay trainer.

This module was extracted from training.grpo_runtime_impl_full to keep the main runtime and trainer implementation small and focused.

src.training.rewards module¶

Thin wrapper around rewards_core to keep legacy imports working.

We only use the crossword/math/rush rewards exposed in rewards_core; the older math_verify/code rewards are intentionally omitted.

src.training.rewards.get_reward_funcs(script_args, ref_model=None, tokenizer=None) → List[Callable][source]¶

Build the list of reward functions requested via script_args.reward_funcs.

The ref_model and tokenizer parameters are accepted for API compatibility with older callers but are not used in the current implementation.

Parameters:

  • script_args – Object exposing a reward_funcs attribute (string or list).

  • ref_model – Legacy reference model argument (ignored).

  • tokenizer – Legacy tokenizer argument (ignored).

Returns:

List of callable reward functions, in the order requested.

Raises:

KeyError – If an unknown reward name is requested.

src.training.rewards_core module¶

Dense-but-precise rewards for GRPO on cryptic crosswords.

Rewarding scheme (all rewards are per-sample and clipped to [0, 1]):

TAGS & TAG FACTOR¶

We look for four tags in the model’s completion: <think>, </think>, <answer>, </answer>. Let present_tags be how many of these appear (0..4). We define:

tag_factor = present_tags / 4.0  # 0.00, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75, 1.00

This tag_factor multiplies the tiny “contains” bonus and the crossword accuracy reward (shaping). The exact-match term remains a strict 0/1.

COMPONENTS¶

  1. Exact match inside ``<answer>…</answer>`` (binary, not scaled by tag_factor)

    • Extract inner <answer> text and canonicalize to a LETTERS-ONLY A–Z string.

    • Compare to canonicalized gold. If equal → base = 1.0, else 0.0.

    • Optional enumeration check: reject if lengths mismatch (see kwargs).

  2. Tiny “contains-anywhere” bonus (scaled by tag_factor)

    • If the gold string appears anywhere in the whole completion as a stand-alone word (not touching letters on either side), add:

      contains_bonus * tag_factor  # default contains_bonus = 0.02

    • “Stand-alone word” means the character immediately before/after the match is not a letter (Unicode-aware). Implemented with lookarounds:

      (?<!LETTER) gold (?!LETTER), LETTER = [^\W\d_]

      so punctuation, quotes, spaces, parentheses, etc. are valid separators; glued forms like foosuite or suitefoo do not trigger the bonus.

  3. Crossword accuracy reward (shaping) (scaled by tag_factor)

    • Canonicalize completion and gold as in (2), and check if the gold appears anywhere. If yes, compute a length factor:

      • 0.0 at <= min_tokens

      • 1.0 by >= max_full_len (linear in between)

    • Multiply by tag_factor and add as:

      + 0.25 * crossword_accuracy_reward

    • Defaults: min_tokens=25, max_full_len=80 (override via kwargs).

FINAL¶

pure_accuracy_reward(...) returns:

clip_0_1(base + contains_bonus * tag_factor + 0.25 * crossword_accuracy)

crossword_accuracy_reward(...) returns the shaping term itself (already tag-scaled and length-scaled), useful when combining rewards explicitly.

keyword - contains_bonus:

kwtype - contains_bonus:

float (default 0.02) tiny bonus magnitude.

keyword - expected_len / n_letters / length / lengths:

checks for exact match.

kwtype - expected_len / n_letters / length / lengths:

enumeration

keyword - min_tokens (int, default 25).:

keyword - max_full_len (int, default 80).:

Notes

  • Lookbehind/ahead assertions are fixed-width and zero-width in Python’s re; we use 1-char letter lookarounds to ensure separate-word matches robustly.

  • We purposely avoid \b word boundaries because \b treats digits and _ as “word” characters, which isn’t the desired notion for crossword “words”.

src.training.rewards_core.crossword_accuracy_reward(completions: List[Any], answer: List[str], **kwargs) → List[float][source]¶

Compute a “contains-anywhere” shaping reward scaled by tag factor and length.

The reward is:

reward = has_gold * length_factor * tag_factor

where:

  • has_gold:

    • contains_mode="any" (default): gold letters appear anywhere (after canon).

    • contains_mode="contiguous": gold letters appear within a single contiguous LETTER+ run.

    • contains_mode="word": gold letters appear as a standalone LETTER+ token.

  • length_factor is 0 at <= min_tokens, 1 at >= max_full_len, with a linear ramp in between.

  • tag_factor is #present_tags / 4.0 with tags in {<think>, </think>, <answer>, </answer>}.

src.training.rewards_core.crossword_format_reward(completions: List[Any], answer: List[str], prompt: List[Any] | None = None) → List[float][source]¶

Formatting bonus for crossword-style tasks.

  • Returns 0.0 if the answer is correct.

  • Returns 1.0 if the answer is wrong but:

    • tags for <think>…</think><answer>…</answer> are present, and

    • the submitted answer is all-uppercase (no lowercase letters).

In all other cases the bonus is 0.0.

src.training.rewards_core.crossword_length_reward(completions: List[Any], prompt: List[Any]) → List[float][source]¶

Reward 1.0 if the answer length matches the enumeration in the prompt, else 0.0. Prompts are expected to include “(N)” where N is the length.

src.training.rewards_core.pure_accuracy_reward(completions: List[Any], answer: List[str], **kwargs) → List[float][source]¶

Exact match reward with a tiny separate-word bonus and optional crossword shaping.

The components are:

  • base: 1.0 iff canonicalized <answer>…</answer> equals the canonicalized gold answer, otherwise 0.0.

  • tiny_bonus: contains_bonus * tag_factor when the canonicalized letters of the gold appear as a standalone LETTER+ word in the normalized completion (no spaces/punctuation inside the match), otherwise 0.0. The underlying regex (case-insensitive) is:

    (?<!LETTER) GOLD_LETTERS (?!LETTER)

    where LETTER = [^\W\d_] and GOLD_LETTERS contains no spaces/punct.

  • shaping: 0.25 * crossword_accuracy_reward(...) (already tag- and length-scaled).

The final reward is min(1.0, base + tiny_bonus + shaping).

src.training.rewards_core.pure_accuracy_reward_math(completions: List[Any], answer: List[str], **_unused_kwargs) → List[float][source]¶

Pure exact-match reward for math problems with a strict formatting requirement.

The model output must:

  • match the pattern <think> … </think><answer> … </answer> (any spacing/newlines)

  • contain an <answer> payload whose canonicalized math form exactly equals the canonicalized gold answer.

src.training.rewards_core.rush_solution_exact(*, prompts, completions, answer=None, gold=None, **kwargs) → List[float][source]¶

Exact-match Rush Hour reward with a small formatting bonus.

Returns 1.0 for canonical sequence matches, otherwise 0.0, with a tiny bonus when the parser fails but the format shows some valid token structure.

src.training.rewards_core.rush_solution_shaped(*, prompts, completions, reward_inputs: _RushRewardInputs | None = None, **kwargs) → List[float][source]¶

Dense, shaped reward in [0, 1] for Rush Hour that works with or without a board.

When a board is provided (board_str + N), legality and Φ-progress are used. When no board is provided, the reward still gives:

  • exact match against gold candidate sequences

  • prefix / longest-common-prefix credit vs gold

  • gold-only “solve optimality”: shorter sequences are better based on gold_moves

reward_inputs can pre-bundle gold/board hints; explicit keyword overrides like gold_moves or board_str still take precedence.

src.training.rush_rewards module¶

rush_rewards.py — Dense Rush Hour reward helpers for GRPO training.

This module was factored out of rewards_core to keep that module within Pylint’s size limits while preserving the public Rush rewards API:

  • rush_solution_shaped

  • rush_solution_exact

The implementation mirrors the original rush section from rewards_core.py.

src.training.rush_rewards.rush_solution_exact(*, prompts, completions, answer=None, gold=None, **kwargs) → List[float][source]¶

Exact-match Rush Hour reward with a small formatting bonus.

Returns 1.0 for canonical sequence matches, otherwise 0.0, with a tiny bonus when the parser fails but the format shows some valid token structure.

src.training.rush_rewards.rush_solution_shaped(*, prompts, completions, reward_inputs: _RushRewardInputs | None = None, **kwargs) → List[float][source]¶

Dense, shaped reward in [0, 1] for Rush Hour that works with or without a board.

When a board is provided (board_str + N), legality and Φ-progress are used. When no board is provided, the reward still gives:

  • exact match against gold candidate sequences

  • prefix / longest-common-prefix credit vs gold

  • gold-only “solve optimality”: shorter sequences are better based on gold_moves

reward_inputs can pre-bundle gold/board hints; explicit keyword overrides like gold_moves or board_str still take precedence.

Module contents¶

Training package init; ensures runtime helpers stay importable in test stubs.
